verses.text: 耶和華對摩西和亞倫說：
「你們要告訴以色列人：地上所有的走獸中，你們可以吃的動物，就是這些：

words.note: Refers to the people of Israel.
Specifically refers to animals that walk on land.

verses.text: 分蹄有趾而且反芻的走獸，你們都可以吃。

words.note: Describes animals with cloven hooves.
Refers to the digits of a foot, particularly in animals.
Describes animals that chew their cud.

verses.text: 但你們不可吃下列反芻，或分蹄的走獸動物：駱駝，因為牠反芻卻不分蹄，你們應以為不潔淨。

words.note: An animal mentioned in Levitical dietary laws.
Modern character specifically for animals (牠), distinct from '他' (he) and '她' (she).

verses.text: 石獾（本章動物名字多不能確定。「石獾」傳統翻譯作「沙番」或「山鼠」），因為牠反芻卻不分蹄，你們應以為不潔淨。

words.note: Refers to the hyrax (Leviticus 11:5).
Refers to the hyrax (Leviticus 11:5).
Here meaning 'is translated as' or 'is rendered as'.
A transliteration of the Hebrew word for hyrax.
Another traditional translation for the hyrax, lit. 'mountain mouse'.

verses.text: 兔子，因為牠反芻卻不分蹄，你們應以為不潔淨。

words.note: Describes animals that ruminate.
Describes animals with split hooves.

verses.text: 豬，因為牠分蹄有趾卻不反芻，你們應以為不潔淨。
這些走獸的肉你們不可吃，牠們的屍體你們不可摸，你們應視為不潔淨。

words.note: Specifically refers to a dead body, often for animals in biblical context.

verses.text: 「水中所有的活物你們可以吃的，就是這些：凡是在水中，有翅有鱗的，不論是在海裡或是河裡的，你們都可以吃。

words.note: Short for 翅膀 (chìbǎng).

verses.heading: Clean and Unclean Water Creatures

verses.text: 在水中游動或生存在水中的活物，無論是在海裡或是河裡，若是沒有翅和鱗的，你們都要當作可憎之物。

words.note: Lit. 'a thing to be hated'.

verses.text: 牠們是你們憎惡之物；牠們的肉，你們不可吃；牠們的屍體，你們要憎惡。

words.note: Often used in religious or formal contexts to express strong aversion.
Classical Chinese particle, similar to '的', often found in formal or religious texts.
Often used in religious or formal contexts to express strong aversion.

verses.text: 所有在水裡沒有翅和鱗的活物，你們都要當作可憎之物。

words.note: Refers to the wing of a bird or insect.
Refers to fish scales.
In a biblical context, often refers to all sentient beings.
Often used in religious texts to describe something morally or ritually offensive.
Classical Chinese particle, similar to '的', often found in formal or religious texts.

verses.text: 「在鳥類中，你們要憎惡，也不可吃這些雀鳥：兀鷹、鵰、鷲、

words.note: Often used in religious or formal contexts to express strong aversion.
A general term for small birds, here referring to a list of specific avian species.
A specific bird species listed as unclean.
A specific bird species listed as unclean.
A specific bird species listed as unclean.

verses.heading: Clean and Unclean Birds

verses.text: 鳶、獵鷹等隼類，

words.note: A specific bird species listed as unclean.
A specific bird species listed as unclean.
A category of birds (falcons) listed as unclean.

verses.text: 所有烏鴉類，

words.note: A category of birds (crows) listed as unclean.

verses.text: 鴕鳥、貓頭鷹、海鷗、蒼鷺等鷹類。

words.note: Lit. 'cat-head eagle'
Lit. 'grey heron'

verses.text: 鴟鶚、鸕鶿、大鴟梟、

words.note: Refers to various kinds of owls/night birds in biblical contexts.
Refers to a specific large owl, often 'horned owl' or 'great owl' in translations.

verses.text: 白鷺、塘鵝、鴇、

words.note: Lit. 'white heron'
Lit. 'pond goose'

verses.text: 鸛、紅鶴等鷺鷥類，戴勝和蝙蝠。

words.note: Lit. 'red crane'
鷺鷥 is a common term for heron/egret.
Refers to the hoopoe bird, known for its distinctive crest.

verses.text: 「凡有翅膀、四足爬行的生物，你們都要當作可憎之物。

words.note: Lit. 'living thing'
Lit. 'can be hated', used frequently in Leviticus for unclean things.
Similar to 'de' (的), often used in more classical/formal contexts.

verses.heading: Clean and Unclean Insects

verses.text: 但在所有有翅膀、四足爬行的生物中，如果有足有腿，能在地上蹦跳的，你們都可以吃。
在昆蟲中，你們可以吃這些：蝗蟲類、螞蚱類、蟋蟀類和蚱蜢類。
但是其他所有有翅膀四足的生物，你們都要當作可憎之物。

words.note: Refers to things forbidden in Mosaic law.
Literary particle, similar to modern '的'.

verses.text: 「以下事物，會使你們成為不潔：觸摸動物屍體的，就不潔淨到晚上。

words.note: Often used in religious/ritualistic contexts.
Often used in religious/ritualistic contexts.

verses.heading: Carcass Uncleanness

verses.text: 拾起牠們的屍體的，就要洗淨自己的衣服，並且不潔淨到晚上。

words.note: Often used in religious/ritualistic contexts.

verses.text: 所有分蹄卻無趾的、不反芻的走獸，你們應以為不潔淨，觸摸牠們的，就不潔淨。

words.note: A specific animal characteristic from Levitical law.
A specific animal characteristic from Levitical law.
Lit. 'reverse chew', describing rumination.
Refers to land animals, often quadrupeds.
Key term in Mosaic law regarding ritual purity.
Key term in Mosaic law regarding ritual purity.

verses.heading: Inedible Land Quadrupeds

verses.text: 所有用四足行走的動物中，用腳掌行走的，你們應以為不潔淨，觸摸牠們屍體的，都不潔淨到晚上。

words.note: Literally 'four feet'.
Key term in Mosaic law regarding ritual purity.
Key term in Mosaic law regarding ritual purity.

verses.text: 拾起牠們屍體的，就要洗淨自己的衣服，並且不潔淨到晚上。以上這些你們應以為不潔淨。

words.note: Key term in Mosaic law regarding ritual purity.
Key term in Mosaic law regarding ritual purity.

verses.text: 「在地上爬行的生物中，你們應以為不潔淨的是這些：鼬鼠、鼫鼠、蜥蜴這一類，

words.note: Key term in Mosaic law regarding ritual purity.
A type of small carnivorous mammal.
Ancient translations often equate 'shrew-mouse' with types of lizards/geckos.

verses.heading: Creatures that Swarm on the Land

verses.text: 以及壁虎、龍子、守宮、蛇醫、變色龍。

words.note: Lit. 'wall tiger', referring to its climbing ability.
Lit. 'dragon child'. Often refers to a small dragon or dragon-like creature.
An archaic term for gecko, traditionally believed to guard palaces.
Lit. 'snake doctor', possibly due to a belief about its medicinal properties or appearance.
Lit. 'color-changing dragon'.

verses.text: 在所有爬行的生物中，你們應以這些為不潔淨；牠們死了以後，觸摸牠們的，都不潔淨到晚上。

words.note: Refers to ritual impurity according to Mosaic law.
Here 'the one who touches them'.
Refers to ritual impurity according to Mosaic law.

verses.text: 牠們當中死了的，掉在甚麼東西上，無論是木器或是衣服，皮子或是布袋等任何器具，都成為不潔淨，要放在水中。但仍不潔淨到晚上，以後就真潔淨了。

words.note: Here 'those which died'.
Etymologically 'east and west'.
Refers to ritual impurity according to Mosaic law.
Refers to ritual impurity according to Mosaic law.
Refers to ritual purity according to Mosaic law.

verses.text: 牠們當中死了的，掉在甚麼瓦器裡，其中不論是甚麼，都成為不潔淨，你們要把瓦器打碎。

words.note: Here 'those which died'.
Specifically refers to earthenware vessels in ritual law.
Refers to ritual impurity according to Mosaic law.
Specifically refers to earthenware vessels in ritual law.

verses.text: 瓦器的水若是滴在任何食物上，食物就成了不潔淨，若是滴在裝了飲料的器皿裡，飲料也成為不潔淨。

words.note: Specifically refers to earthenware vessels in ritual law.
Refers to ritual impurity according to Mosaic law.
Refers to ritual impurity according to Mosaic law.

verses.text: 牠們屍體的任何部分掉在甚麼東西上，那東西就不潔淨，無論是爐或是鍋，都成為不潔淨，應該打碎；你們應以這些為不潔淨。

words.note: Etymologically 'east and west'.
Etymologically 'east and west'.
Refers to ritual impurity according to Mosaic law.
Refers to ritual impurity according to Mosaic law.
Refers to ritual impurity according to Mosaic law.

verses.text: 但是水源和儲水池仍算是潔淨的。只有觸摸水中屍體的，才是不潔淨。

words.note: Commonly used in religious contexts for ritual purity.
Frequent in purity laws; also used in modern contexts like forensics.
Turns the preceding phrase into a noun equivalent.
Opposite of 潔淨, used for ritual impurity.

verses.text: 牠們屍體的一部分掉在要播種的種子上，種子還是潔淨的；

words.note: The character 牠 is specifically for animals.
Postposition indicating location 'on'.

verses.text: 但是，如果種子已經澆了水，牠們屍體的一部分才掉在種子上面，你們應以這種子為不潔淨。

words.note: Verb-complement structure with 了 indicating completion.
Functions as a location noun or postposition.
Often used in structures like '以 A 為 B' (to take A as B).
Part of the '以...為...' structure.

verses.text: 「一隻你們可以吃的走獸死了，誰摸了牠的屍體，就不潔淨到晚上；

words.note: Refers to land animals; distinct from birds or fish.

verses.heading: Edible Land Quadrupeds

verses.text: 誰吃了牠的屍體，就要洗淨自己的衣服，並且不潔淨到晚上；誰拾起這屍體，也要洗淨自己的衣服，並且不潔淨到晚上。

words.note: A resultative compound verb, 'wash' until 'clean'.

verses.text: 「所有在地上爬行的動物，都是可憎之物，都不可吃。

words.note: Indicates totality.
Literally 'able to be hated'.
Classical Chinese equivalent of '的'.
Acts as a single modal prohibition.

verses.text: 凡是用肚子，或用四足或是多足在地上爬行的動物，你們都不可吃，因為牠們是可憎之物。

words.note: Acts as a single modal prohibition.
Literally 'able to be hated'.
Classical Chinese equivalent of '的'.

verses.text: 你們不可因任何爬行的動物使自己成為可憎的，也不可因牠們玷污自己，以致不潔淨。

words.note: Acts as a single modal prohibition.
Literally 'able to be hated'.
Turns '可憎' into 'the detestable'.
Acts as a single modal prohibition.

words.definition: so that, with the result that

verses.text: 因為我是耶和華你們的 神，所以你們要使自己成為聖潔。你們要分別為聖，因為我是聖潔的。你們不可因在地上爬行的任何動物玷污自己，

words.note: Transliteration of the Hebrew divine name.
Used as a proper noun for the Abrahamic God.

words.definition: be set apart as holy, sanctify
words.note: A compound verb meaning 'to consecrate'.
Turns '聖潔' into 'the holy one'.
Acts as a single modal prohibition.

verses.text: 因為我是耶和華，曾把你們從埃及地領上來，為要作你們的 神；你們要分別為聖，因為我是聖潔的。」

words.note: Transliteration of the Hebrew divine name.
Used to bring the object before the verb.
埃及 (Āijí) is Egypt, 地 (dì) is land.
Directional complement indicating movement upwards and towards the speaker/point of reference.

words.definition: in order to, for the purpose of

breakdown.m: to want, to be going to

words.note: Used as a proper noun for the Abrahamic God.

words.definition: be set apart as holy, sanctify
words.note: A compound verb meaning 'to consecrate'.
Turns '聖潔' into 'the holy one'.

verses.text: 以上就是有關走獸、飛禽、所有在水中游行的動物，和所有在地上爬行的動物的律例，

words.note: Refers to animals that walk on land, often used in religious/classical contexts.
Refers to flying animals; common in religious and literary texts.
In this context, it refers to movement in water, not a public parade.
Frequently used in legal and religious contexts, especially for divine laws.

verses.text: 為要把不潔淨的和潔淨的，可吃的生物和不可吃的生物，分別出來。

breakdown.m: to want, to be about to

words.note: Indicates purpose or intention.
Introduces the object of a verb, indicating it is to be acted upon.
Central concept in biblical laws regarding ritual purity.
Central concept in biblical laws regarding ritual purity.
Functions as a resultative or directional complement, often implying a clearer distinction or appearance.
